sa156:1.2: One time, the Buddha stayed at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove in Śrāvastī.
sa156:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa156:2.2: “What is it that exists, that arises, that ties, that’s an attachment, and that’s viewed as self and causes sentient beings to create such views and such statements?
sa156:2.3: ‘Sentient beings are alive in this world.
sa156:2.4: After death, they are destroyed and become non-existent.
sa156:2.5: The four elements combine to form a man.
sa156:2.6: When his life ends, earth returns to earth, water returns to water, fire returns to fire, wind returns to wind, and his faculties turn into space.
sa156:2.7: The bier bed being fifth, four people carry his dead body to the graveyard …
sa156:2.9: After he’s burned, his bones are made white as a dove.
sa156:2.10: The conceited know generosity, and the intelligent know acceptance.
sa156:2.11: Those who say [its fruit] exists are all vain and speaking falsely.
sa156:2.12: Whether foolish or wise, in the other world after death, they are both destroyed and become non-existent.’”
sa156:3.1: The monks said to the Buddha,
sa156:3.2: “The Bhagavān is the Dharma root, the Dharma eye, and the Dharma refuge …”
sa156:3.3: *It’s thus explained in detail and in the sequence of the three sutras (35.7-9) above.*
